video.title: Linux for Ethical Hackers (Kali Linux Tutorial)
video.description:
In this course, you will learn the basics of Kali Linux. The course covers installation, using the terminal / command line, bash scripting, tools and features for ethical hacking, and more. The course focuses on Kali Linux but much of the content applies to other versions of Linux as well.

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ Installing VMWare / Kali Linux
⌨️ Kali Linux Overview
⌨️ Navigating the File System
⌨️ Users and Privileges
⌨️ Common Network Commands
⌨️ Viewing, Creating, and Editing Files
⌨️ Starting and Stopping Services
⌨️ Installing and Updating Tools
⌨️ Scripting with Bash

🎥 Course created by The Cyber Mentor. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0ArlFuFYMpEewyRBzdLHiw
🐦 The Cyber Mentor on Twitter: https://twitter.com/thecybermentor

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news



https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=coQ5dg8wM2o

topLevelComment.author: CallousCoder
topLevelComment.text:
Silly question but why would a company hire people who merely run OTS tools? They can do that themselves. Or in our cases we build them in the CI/CD pipeline to catch the obvious code issues that these tools also check for during the CI process. And when those are triggered there won’t be a release build so the potentially exploitabel code cannot even be released.
And a good company has their own Linter team that writes Lints for their code stack.

Because usually the security problem lies a lot deeper, such as in code (even zero days as recently OpenSSL (again) and privilege access management and the required interoperability with other systems, teams or worse over the internet clients/businesses.
Rights structures on the cloud are incredibly complex these days and having a infrastructure as code solution with least privileged approach everything over private endpoints no public access enabled. Only access to your middleware and back end over mutual certificate authentication. And very strict oauth2 and eidm for the public side. With inspection. But that sort of thing I hardly see any security “expert” talk about or actually know about.

We all can run standard tools that others made. But 99% of these “white hats”, couldn’t even write proper code themselves. Could’ve develop an egg drop if their life depends on it.
Just script kiddies with a course 😂

topLevelComment.author: Grecu Cristian
topLevelComment.text: I have some problems inside the terminal. I have installed the latest version as we're in 2022 and it seems like the default account is kali/kali but when I try to go back with cd root I get an permissions denied error. Why is that?

replies.author: Grecu Cristian
replies.text: Resolved it. As I was logged as Kali user (the new Kali Linux image had a kali default account instead of the root/toor, I had to reset the root password (sudo passwd root)>Set the password> Installed the root package (sudo apt -y install kali-root-login)>Logged off and logged in with root/new password.

topLevelComment.text:
Error while powering on: This host supports Intel VT-x, but Intel VT-x is disabled.

Intel VT-x might be disabled if it has been disabled in the BIOS/firmware settings or the host has not been power-cycled since changing this setting.

(1) Verify that the BIOS/firmware settings enable Intel VT-x and disable 'trusted execution.'

(2) Power-cycle the host if either of these BIOS/firmware settings have been changed.

(3) Power-cycle the host if you have not done so since installing VMware Player.

(4) Update the host's BIOS/firmware to the latest version.

topLevelComment.author: Will Power
topLevelComment.text: The /etc/ folder is actually the "Et cetera" folder, not to be pronounced like Etsy.  Etsy is a cool site to buy cool stuff. "Et Cetera" is a latin phrase meaning "and other similar things" or "and so forth".  But that is the "et cetera" folder /etc/, in no way to be pronounced Etsy.  Just letting you know due to you being a professional, you don't want to sound silly while you are presenting and teaching.  Speaking of latin.....    "Acta est fabula, plaudite!"   Augustus Ceasars last words.

replies.author: dotslashconfigure
replies.text: @Yasser Mamdouh Pentesting tools are short for "penetration testing tools". Basically, they are a bunch of tools used to test the security of software applications and networks. These are the same tools which are used for hacking. As for a linux distro for personal use, I prefer arcolinux or pop_os. If you want a distro with pentration testing tools, go for parrot os or kali linux. If you are a power user and want to say "I use arch", along with some hacking tools, go with blackarch. My personal favourite distro right now is KDE Neon, mostly because of the customisablity kde offers.

replies.author: Yasser Mamdouh
replies.text: @dotslashconfigure what is < Pentesting Tools > & mainly ,which distro in Linux is suitable for personal usage ?

replies.author: dotslashconfigure
replies.text: Because Kali* linux is the only distro among the ones you mentioned that comes pre-installed with pentesting tools

topLevelComment.author: Oren Wolfe
topLevelComment.text:
It is now almost 2022. This video is showing its age: e.g., the Python SimpleHTTPServer does not work with Python 3 (3.10 to be exact).
You should also mention that VMWare emulator is not available for MacOS - only for Win and Lin. Could not get the VBox prebuilt to install - did not come with an .iso file.
For those of us who are not Newbies to unix/linux, how about a session on using Kali tools to do some actual hacking. Sitting through 75 minutes of linux kindergarten before getting to the meat of Kali is a bit tedious.

topLevelComment.author: Chess Player
topLevelComment.text:
(notes on the chapter "Navigating the file system, I will keep on adding the notes in the reply section as I write them,the notes include the commands,what do they do, and examples)

pwd
    present working directory,used to check the place we are at

cd
    change directory, to go back to previous directory we can use cd..

ls
    returns everything present in our directory
       they are colour coded depending on the permissio setting

   ls (directory of x)
       used to look at what is in the directory x even if x and I are not in the same place
           example:cd /asd/x
               (you have to put a slash at the front since it is the absolute 1st directory)

   ls x/
       used to check what is in the directory x(only works if x and I are in the same directory)
   ls -la
       ls -list all,used to see all directories in my current directories(even the once which are hidden in just the ls command)
       can be used to ssee permission settings for the stuffs in the directory

cd x/
    used to enter the directory named x in our current directory
        the terminal can autofill the name if the folder
   cd (directory of x)
       used to enter the directory named x even if x and I are not in the same directory
           example:cd /asd/x/

   cd (some letters)
       this will show the directories that start with those letters(you have to click tab once or maybe twice for this)

   cd /saev/wev/wev/x can be replaced with cd -/x/   ( (-) represents the home page or the root page and does not require / before it)

mkdir (the word you want to name your directory)
    make directory, used to create a new directory in your current directory

rmdir (the name of the directory)/
    remove directory, used to remove a directory

   rm (the file with it's directory)
       used to remove a file even without being in the same directory.

cp (file name with format) (location)/
    copy file to somewhere,
    example:
    cp abce.txt Downloads/ (note: the location has to be present in our current directory)

mv (file name with format) (location)/
    move file to somewhere, works like cp (file name with format) (location)/ but instead of copying,you cut

locate (file name)
    no need to say the use since it is obvious

updatedb
    update database

passwd
    password, used to change password

man (command name)
    manual(that is what I think) ,used to get information about various commands if you need
    example:
    man ls (gives a lot of information about ls)
(command name) --help
    close to man (command name)

topLevelComment.author: John Tyson
topLevelComment.text: Very nice work as always by TCM. To improve this video, it would be nice to be able to jump directly to the chapters. When in the terminal, it would be nice to enlarge the font size. And after I download Kali 2021.3, which was the latest version, I was surprised at the number of tools I needed to update. When I tried updating everything, which was recommended, while running apt-update && apt-upgrade I got a scary error msg stating the GRUB Boot Loader that was previously installed to a disk is no longer present or whose unique identifier has been changed for some reason...  I wasn't sure if this screwed up my VirtualBox machine or my real machine or didn't do anything at all, so I CTRL+C out of it. Fortunately, nothing appears to be damaged. I think the best practice would be to search for an update before using the tool you're about to use.

topLevelComment.author: John Tamplin
topLevelComment.text:
So, while there is some good content in here, there's a few problems with this video, the main one being the title. If the title was "An introduction to Linux, using the Kali distro" then I think it would be much better because there is very little here about hacking. The most relevant part is the 'additional resources/bonus material' which is just the last 10 mins, and most of which points to other websites.
But even then, the coverage was very uneven (like the sound volume, another problem). For example, some of the most basic topics were covered in depth (fine if you're targeting beginners), but then other more useful topics were skipped over as if you think people already understand them. And I lost count of how many times you said "we'll talk about that later" (or similar) but you never covered it. 
My advice (which of course you can ignore if you want):
- Decide who your target audience is ... beginners/intermediate/advanced ... general linux users/newbie pen testers/advanced pen testers?
- Plan your content according to the target audience. You've got lots of good stuff, but it's all over the place
- Re-title the video!

#!/bin/bash

topLevelComment.author: Random stuffs
topLevelComment.text:
Error while powering on: This host supports Intel VT-x, but Intel VT-x is disabled.

Intel VT-x might be disabled if it has been disabled in the BIOS/firmware settings or the host has not been power-cycled since changing this setting.

(1) Verify that the BIOS/firmware settings enable Intel VT-x and disable 'trusted execution.'

(2) Power-cycle the host if either of these BIOS/firmware settings have been changed.

(3) Power-cycle the host if you have not done so since installing VMware Player.

(4) Update the host's BIOS/firmware to the latest version.

This host does not support "Intel EPT" hardware assisted MMU virtualization.

VMware Player does not support the user level monitor on this host.

Module 'MonitorMode' power on failed.

Failed to start the virtual machine.



Can u please suggest something for this.

replies.author: Michael Lavender
replies.text: hey there, if you restart your machine and hit either F12, F11 or del depending on your machine, you will enter the bios, inside there will be the setting which will need to be enabled, it will either say VT-x , or VMware , or it will say something along the lines of virtualization or VMM, hope this helps you :)

if there's no hash pass, then configure your pass.
sudo passwd root

replies.author: abdi abdulaziz

replies.author: abdi abdulaziz
replies.text: Run as root or type sudo and then the file like sudo ./test.sh for example, of this doesn’t work then the file has to be executable, you can fix this error by type $ chmod u=rwx <file_namere_here> like this - chmod u=rwx file.sh.  chmod is the program, rwx stand for r = read,  w = write and x = execute the file. The math part: r = 4, w = 2 and x = 1. There’s many ways to do it, if you want more information, search on google Linux file permission!

replies.text:
okay so i figured it out
#!/bin/bash

if [ "$1" == "" ]
then
echo "You forgot an IP address!"
echo "Syntax: ./ipsweep.sh 192.168.1"

else
for ip in {1..254} ; do
ping -c 1 $1.$ip | grep "64 bytes" | cut -d " " -f 4 | tr -d ":" &
done
fi

topLevelComment.author: VIPERZCREW
topLevelComment.text:
If you try to use the current cut script (ping) on bash it won't work. 
You can manually use this :

#!/bin/bash
# Simple Host Pinger
e=$(route | head -3 | tail -1 | sed 's/         / /g' | cut -d\  -f2 | cut -d"." -f1-3)
for ip in `seq 1 254`;
do
	sudo ping -c 1 ${e}.${ip} | grep "64 bytes" | cut -d\  -f4 | tr -d ":" | awk '{print "\033[32;1m[*] \033[37;1mLIVE HOST: \033[32;1m" $1}' &

done

For execute:
chmod +x scan.sh
./scan.sh

(No Arguments)

What it does ?

It will search for local gateway using route, then it will remove the last ip field to add later the seq 1..254.
After then it ping by multi-thread and print out only live hosts which are ping-able without any tool.
 
POWER FOR BASH

topLevelComment.author: masquerade01
topLevelComment.text:
BTW, to all of you who may have gotten stuck on the ipsweep script, line 1 is #!/bin/bash  and line 3 has backticks before seq and after 254 not single quotes.

So:

#!/bin/bash

for ip in `seq 1 254` ; do
ping -c 1 $1.$ip | grep "64 bytes" | cut -d " " -f 4 | tr -d ":" &
done

topLevelComment.author: Sharan Kumar
topLevelComment.text: Hey! Heath can I take up this course with a persistent USB having Kali Linux...?

replies.author: SlusheeWolf2
replies.text: Yes, as long as the USB is NOT a live boot and is a fully working OS that lets you save files to it. You have to make sure the target system has the boot order modified in BIOS if you want to boot up your computer with the USB OS. Please note. The files provided in the tutorial are for virtual machines only. If you want to install an OS to a flash drive, you have to seek out the ISO from the official Kali Linux website and install it like a real Operating System into the USB. Be careful with overriding any hard drives that are not the USB drive.

topLevelComment.author: Max Tan
topLevelComment.text:
Is UNIX is linux?? and is kali linux part of Linux??

I almost crazy!!!

replies.author: SlusheeWolf2
replies.text:
No. Unix was depreciated years ago due to security concerns.
Linux is an open-source OS that anyone can edit to create their own version of, as long as they credit Linux.
Unix used to be owned by AT&T and they started commercializing it, which is why Linux was developed. It behaves similar to Unix as it was originally a way to give consumers an alternative to Unix without having to pay for usage.

topLevelComment.author: Tony Su
topLevelComment.text:
As noted in the pinned comments,
This is not really a tutorial describing how to use Kali pentesting,
This is more a Introduction/FAQ and first steps to running a rolling release Debian (Which is what Kali is built on).

Pluses:
For awhile, this tutorial demos on a recent Kali and VMware Player versions (Still relevant May 2020) which can be important. There are many good Kali videos but Kali has been around so long that old content loses relevance sometimes... Procedures, tools and requirements change over time.
Covers a number of very basic maintenance and a very elementary scripting that can automate tasks.

Minuses:
The presentation content is very weak on proper terminology and definition or depth often. Nothing I've noticed where things don't work, but it's never too early to learn things as "properly" as possible so that things don't have to be re-learned or unlearned later.
Not knowing how to pronounce terminology correctly, like SEE-QUEL(alternatively spelling out the letters SQL), POST-GREZ-SEE-QUEL, SYSTEMCONTROL and mixing legacy commands like "service apache2" when you should change entirely to the new "systemctl" commands.
When installing in a Virtualization technology, you should install Guest enhancements (VMware Tools or Virtualbox Guest Additions) which at this time is not already installed in the Guest image. There also are various highly recommended settings in the HostOS part of the virtualization besides the most essential that are described.
Why things are done a certain way at times, eg why a person might want to install Veil from github source instead of the Debian packages.
Regarding the scripting specifically, I'd recommend defining your target audience in detail. Because this video is obviously targeted to the person very unfamiliar with scripting, IMO every part of the scripting should have been described which were skipped over like the use of variable.

Bottom line,
The content is on the level of a noob which I wouldn't really criticize because everyone starts somewhere.
But, I'd ask that the content be prepared a bit better to elevate from "OK" to "I'd recommend." The numerous small inaccuracies which don't seem important immediately are nevertheless not helpful as the viewer advances in knowledge.

topLevelComment.author: Vince Huff
topLevelComment.text: New to computer need help please. When I push play virtual machine I see. Host has 1 cpu. Virtual machine  is configured to run with 4 cpu. Does that mean I need a computer with 4 cpu I thought computer on had 1 cpu or does that mean the speed if the cpu. This is a old computer I had in storage

replies.author: SlusheeWolf2
replies.text:
No, you need to change the settings to be 1 CPU.
A "guest" machine is only going to run off what your current hardware has. If you have 4 cores in your CPU, you can allocate cores to the virtual machine in settings.
Be careful though, because if you give the guest too much power, it will make your host computer slow.
If I have 16GB of RAM, I usually only need to feed the guest 8GB, because if i give it any more, my host will start lagging since it also has programs running outside of the VM.

First, thank you for your service; and putting the uniform on!

I am glad that I some how stumbled across your channel; I am actually more interested in learning how to apply enhanced layers of security.

I was hacked on 05.31.19 and had three years of mining block rewards stolen, ( approximately $16k at the time ), and I no longer keep anything on any of my systems at home.

Back in the day; around 1991, I wrote some software for DOD in languages long since out dated these days, ( GWBasic ). 

I once attempted to setup some mining rigs running on Linux and quickly realized I needed to get a tad  smarter on the OS.

I remember back when hacker was associated as a good term; we use to write in additional features into modules not included in the original software packages; then later it became demonized and rolled in with smackers, and crackers.

Thanks for providing this tutorial; I have been wanting to learn more about linux; but got momentarily distracted in mapping bitstreams on fpga's.

Peace

topLevelComment.author: unknown
topLevelComment.text:
1) is there any special permission that would allow the user to change the permissions (chmod rwx) or owner (chown) of the file.


EXAMPLE: user named usr_1 created a file hui.cpp with the following permissions "- r w x- - - - -x"  
then the usr_2 that is not in the filegroup wants to change permissions using chmod command or change the owner to itself. in order to access the contents of the file. 
 
2) what happens when the exact same file is transferred from one system to another in which there is no usr_1 using FTP, TFTP, SCP, or any other transfer protocol? Who is going to be the owner of the file and who is going to  be the new owner.

topLevelComment.author: GibsonGuitarPlayer27
topLevelComment.text: If you are using the new KALI VMware image dated 2020.1 or newer, the default user and password are "kali" (without the quotes). In order to run commands as root while in a Terminal session you need to first run the command "sudo su -" (without the quotes), and then type the password for your kali username when prompted. This will allow you to run all commands with root privileges.

replies.author: cranberry vr
replies.text: Idk if you're still reading this comment section but maybe someone else does. From my understanding from talking to professionals in the field, OSCP is a lot harder to get and makes for a much better resume, especially for an entry level job. What matters most is having the hands-on skills; certs wont get you a job if you can't actually do the job, but a cert requires can provide a roadmap to get the ball rolling. CEH is becoming more obsolete from what I am told and is more of a general overview.

topLevelComment.author: Davy Rogers
topLevelComment.text:
To all you whining ‘click bait’ merchants in the comments... This video was one video from an entire series of videos around Ethical Hacking, Heath does an absolutely amazing job with his videos, what’s more... he provides them for free for people to learn. 

If you’re complaining, your completely missing the point... a total noob wanting to get into ethical hacking will find this video EXTREMELY useful and it’s a MUST if you want to learn this stuff properly... you have to start somewhere, this is it! 

If you are more ‘advanced’ than the contents of the video, great!!.. good for you!! ....go make your own video and put it up for people to learn. Drop me a note, I’ll help you sharer around! 

Stop your whining. This is a spectacular contribution to the community. 

Great video Heath! As always!

topLevelComment.author: Angry Old Canadian
topLevelComment.text:
I found Kali linux to be very resource intensive.  I have a netbook where I first installed Kali... I even upgraded it to 8gb ram, but it ran slower than Win 10.  I installed Parrot as the base OS and it flies.  I've even run steam on it and can play games.  

I know Kali is the most popular, but I would highly recommend Parrot OS if your system isn't a high end system.

topLevelComment.author: Dave Lampton
topLevelComment.text: 3:40 This course has little to do with hacking, ethical or otherwise. It's essentially a very basic introduction to Linux and the terminal for complete beginners, that happens to be demonstrated on a virtual instance of Kali. The term "ethical hackers" in the video's title is misleading clickbait.
